Basic: It Follows is a supernatural teen indie horror film. Set in the 1980s, around autumn, a 19 year-old girl name Jay (played by Maika Monroe) dates a man, who's in the same age like her. One moment in the film, we see these two characters having sex in a car, and then this person that she's dating, drugged her. Later, she wakes up, sees herself tied up in a wheelchair, and the person, who was dating her and drugged her, tries to tell her that he passed over this kind of curse to her when they were having sex in the car, and now it's going to hunt her down, and kill her. The kind of curse that's upon to Maika's character, Jay, is a mysterious figure that can disguise to anyone she knows or a stranger in a crowd. Now, all of her friends (Keir Gilchirst, Olivia Luccardi, and Daniel Zovatto), and her sister, Kelly, (played by Lili Sepe) are not only going to protect Jay, but also getting rid of this mysterious figure that's hunting her down. All of these actors or actresses may not be familiar to you, but I do remember Keir Gilchirst in "It's kind of a funny story" and Maika Monroe in "The Guest". Plus, she's also going to be in The 5th Wave, and Independence Day: Resurgence.What's the deal: Well, to be quite honest, I really like this film, and not only that it is one of the greatest horrors film that I've ever seen (even though I haven't yet saw The Babadook), but it's also one of those movies that I would rank it on my Top 5 best films in 2015. Everything about this movie just left me so effective. Now before I begin my reasons to why I really like this movie, I would to explain all the similarities and the influences in this movie because there's so much to talk about it.The storyline to It Follows is kind of like "Drag me to Hell". The fact, that the main character is a female, and she has this curse, of where these demons or monsters from hell, are trying to take her to hell, except in It Follows, it really doesn't have any demons or monsters from hell, that want to take her to hell. All we have in It Follows is a mysterious figure, who's trying to hunt this main character down, and kill her. But the one movie that this movie refers back to the most is John Carpenter's Halloween, mostly because of its setting, its visuals, its camerawork, and its music. The biggest setting in It Follows is the neighborhood. The music goes completely pumped up, when something scary is about to happen, which Halloween certainly does that. There's also a shot in It Follows of where Maika's character, Jay is walking with her sister, Kelly at the neighborhood, which it has this similar shot in Halloween of where Jamie Lee Curtis is walking with her friends around the neighborhood. Plus, there are a couple moments of where it reminded me of Blow-Out. One, for example, of where Jay and Greg (played by Daniel Zovatto) are inside of a public library and the camera swirls around it, when they're in there, just like in Blow-Out of where John Travolta's character is in his recording room, and the camera swirls around it, when he finds out that all of his tapes are erased. So, anyway, the film really does pull out a lot of references to other films, mostly to Halloween but that doesn't mean it's a problem to me. I think, writer-director David Robert Mitchell does it all in the right places, and that's one of the reasons of why I was impressed with the film.To start off with all of my reasons to why I really like the film are the characters. I was really connected with the characters, and I certainly, at times, feel for them. I never at all find them at least campy or silly like the ones in the Final Destination movies. I do see that Jay's sister, Kelly, and all of her friends really do care about Jay; they want to protect her because she's the main character, who's in danger. Of course, there's a character in the film, his name is Paul (played by Keir Gilchrist, who was in "It's kind of a funny story", which I already mention that), he's friends with Kelly, and he also works with her in an Ice Cream shop, but he secretly has a crush on Jay. I actually thought Maika Monroe and Keir Gilchrist look good when they're onscreen together.Another thing that I really like about this film is its camerawork. A lot of the shots have wider angles, and closer angles, but they certainly do make it look scary, while they're using it. I was more impressed with it than its eerie, pumped up score. The most memorable and craziest scene in the movie that made me go, "Wow" is the one at the beach, and I absolutely don't want to give away that scene because, obviously, it's better for you to watch it than for me to tell you it. The ending of the movie is ambiguous. I like how it ended, and that's all I got to say about it. My full opinion: It Follows has characters that I really do connect with them, lots of camerawork that I was really impressed with, a lot of references to other films that does it in all the right ways, and of course, lots of scariness.-Okay, maybe it's not scary for everybody, and I can totally see why they would say that, but as for me, I find the tension of the film fascination. It has everything I want it for a horror movie to be, and mostly, I was really impressed with this way more than Oculus. 9.3/10

There seems to be quite a few films recently which hearken back to the late 70's/early 80's in terms of filmmaking style. IT FOLLOWS is one of the films in this mold that capture a certain feeling of nostalgia while also having its foot firmly planted in the present. It's about a vague entity that follows you around after having sex with somebody who also has the same problem. Inasmuch as the Friday THE 13TH series was about abstinence, IT FOLLOWS is in a similar vein, with a heavy dose of John Carpenter's HALLOWEEN and Wes Craven for good measure. The most outstanding part of this film is the subtle approach taken with the horror, letting it build quietly without using the score to jolt you. There was also great care taken with the direction and cinematography that helped to build an atmosphere of tension and dread. Even without being a horror movie (albeit, more of a psychological one), the cinematography and camera-work was excellent, with precise, deliberate movement, slow pans and zooms, etc. It was quite artful, to say the least. I should also mention the outstanding score by Disasterpeace, which captures a feeling I haven't felt since watching HALLOWEEN. So, at least on the surface, IT FOLLOWS has a lot going for it. However, I do ask a little bit more from movies I watch than to impress me visually and aurally, and apart from these qualities, IT FOLLOWS was quite banal. The acting was decent, although no one really stood out from the rest. The potential in the setup for this "it" to be anything or anyone allowed for a few good sequences, but it also meant that the narratively was a little too linear for my tastes. It boils down to have sex, wait, and run. And for a 100 minute film, I expected more. There wasn't even an underlying emotional subtext like was in THE BABADOOK. Still, despite being bored through parts of it, the film does manage to pull together for a decent (and appropriate) finish. I would recommend people to see this, but don't go in expecting something revolutionary. There is a little bit of subtext about abstinence/STDs that can be read into IT FOLLOWS and, courtesy of a CHARADE billboard, possibly some meta-commentary on artificiality. However, IT FOLLOWS works perfectly fine as a stylistic exercise that aspires to little more than imitating its cinematic forebears, and does an admittedly good job at it.

It Follows. The perfect title to understand this brilliant horror flick - two words that sum up all the great tense moments of this film with a clear explanation.The premise - this supernatural figure follows you. There is only one of it, it only walks and never runs, and it will kill you. It can look like anybody and only people who have "had it" can see it. Why does it follow? If somebody who "has it" has sex with you, they pass it on (a likely metaphor for STD's) and you become the new target.It may sound really simple, but that is the beauty of it. It follows you wherever you go, but it has a slow pace, not unlike a zombie. It follows you in a straight path and kills you if it has the chance to get close to you. What is creepier than basically being stalked and having no idea when your stalker will get to you?What helps induce horror in the audience is the techno, heavy-bass style music not unlike the music in horror classic Halloween by John Carpenter. It really sets the tone for the film, and has an eerie feel to it, which keeps reminding you that there is something wrong and disturbing with this world.Trust issues are a heavy theme in this film and understandably so. The main character "gets it" from a guy she goes on a few dates with, but he explains the situation to her in order to warn her and help get her out of the situation. Guys she knows want to protect her and take "it" away from her, but she is hesitant on letting certain people have it, especially her good friend Paul. On a couple occasions, however, characters attempt to pass it on to complete strangers - they would have no regrets if strangers die because of them. The idea of sexuality can, and should be discussed in great detail when analyzing this film.Is it a perfect film? No. I believe it is very difficult to make a "perfect" horror movie, but this one keeps you on the edge of your seat while simultaneously making you question the idea of sex, making for a great, layered horror movie.

Incredibly disturbing, It Follows is a creepy and atmospheric low-budget indie horror film. An allegory about STDs (in part), the story follows a young girl who, after having sex with her boyfriend, is stalked by a mysterious shapeshifting creature that can only be seen by those who've had sex with an infected person, and it can only be escaped from (for a time) by passing on the infection to another person through sex. Maika Monroe gives a strong performance that's nuanced and really shows her struggle to come to grips with her situation. However, the director makes some odd choices in creating a setting, as it comes off as a strange alternative reality with a mixture of futuristic and retro fashions and technologies (which is quite distracting). Additionally, the creature effects are rather grotesque; with the creature often appearing mangled and in various stages of nudity. A problematic film, It Follows delivers some effective scares, but the who and the what are so vague that the story ends up being rather unsatisfying.

Understated and intelligent, "It Follows" offers a haunting portrait of true psychological terror. A teenage girl becomes the recipient of a deadly curse that she and her friends must try to escape before it claims another victim. Writer-director David Robert Mitchell creates an unrelenting sense of dread and paranoia through cinematography and sound. Slowly and methodically, the camera stalks its adolescent targets, while the synth soundtrack strategically pulses at all the right moments. While mostly unsettling, "It Follows" also has its slyly comic, self-aware moments. Mitchell employs a fine brigade of young actors to inhabit his eerie suburban wasteland. Reigning queen of indie horror Maika Monroe ("The Guest") is once again a standout, conveying a palpable sense of trauma and fear. Like the best horror, 'It Follows" is a metaphorically rich fable where the symbolism takes on multiple meanings. At its most literal, the film serves as a twisted sex-ed class, but Mitchell's shape-shifting harbinger of doom more subtly represents the inevitable extinction of youth and impending mortality. Death, inescapable and universal, is the one foe that cannot be defeated - the one fear that, at one point or another, shakes us all to the core.

In 1978 John Carpenter's Halloween launched the "Slasher Film" sub-genre. While technically not the first film of it's kind, it was definitely the first breakout hit and it's simple formula has been shamelessly copied by ... I'll say hundreds of films at this point, some better than others. This formula has single handedly launched at least a dozen entire HORROR FILM FRANCHISES, most of which have been remade in the last 10 years. And the baffling part of all of this is: none of these subsequent films have ever figured out what made Carpenter's original Halloween scary. The copy-cat slashers that followed all zeroed in on the following elements; teen sex, violence, and the general plot involving a masked killer stalking a group of teens. Obviously all those are key ingredients in Halloween, but that's not why it works. It works because of it's ability to create tension. How does it do this? Because it is patient. It takes it's time. In Michael Myers, Carpenter created a mindless shape of evil that is rarely seen, but who's presence is felt in every moment. This presence haunts and follows Jamie-Lee Curtis's Laurie Stode, without explanation. (Yes I am choosing to ignore their brother-sister backstory that was revealed in Part II after Carpenter admitted he ran out of ideas while trying to write a sequel he never intended.) These elements of tone and atmosphere where really what made Halloween so fresh and terrifying and it's fascinating how in all the films that followed these elements were basically dropped completely in favor of nudity and gore. It's understandable though. Nudity and gore are easy. Finding a filmmaker that understands and has the ability to successfully create and sustain tension throughout an entire film, well that's rare. This is why It Follows is so special. This is a film that boils down every slasher film to it's core elements and then doubles down on all the elements that used to make slasher films work, but have been forgotten and buried under piles of cheap knock-offs and the uninspired garbage that springs to mind when you think of any contemporary horror film. This film is pure, sweet terror, and if rubbed upon one's gums will give the satisfying pleasure that only comes along once in a very great while, and that is, a truly GREAT HORROR FILM.

"It could look like someone you know or it could be a stranger in a crowd. Whatever helps it get close to you."Over the past few years the horror genre has been plagued with complete bullshit (a fucking board game?!) That said there are some wonderful gems that still do the genre justice. A genre which once thrived on getting inside the audience's head through psychological horror via tension, apprehension, atmosphere, suspense and our fear of the unknown seems all but forgotten now. These days the genre gets most it's scares out of the over use of jump scares which startle for a brief second but don't genuinely terrify. Not all jump scares are a bad thing however. Some can be truly effective beyond the initial "jump in your seat moment." It is the "false" jump scare that is the problem. There's a difference between a jump scare of a lamp crashing or [insert loud noise here] and a jump scare where the "antagonist" shows his face through a hole in the door. One of those is inconsequential to the story at large while the other has a purpose beyond just making you jump (I trust you can figure out which example applies to which scare. If not I have some bad news for you...) Another problem with horror is the audience itself. They've forgotten what real horror really is. If someone ever asks me "was it scary?" I'm hesitant to answer because by today's standards "scary" for the most part means "did I jump in my seat?" To me and many fans more well versed in the genre than myself, that is not what horror is about. Or at the very least it is a very small part of it. Having said all this, is "It Follows" the type of film the horror genre has been sorely missing these past few years? Or is it just another jump scare fest to be piled on top of all the other bullshit?Story"It Follows", directed by David Robert Mitchell, stars Maika Monroe (most recently seen in "The Guest") as a teenager named Jay living in the suburbs of Detroit. Jay is your typical well-to-do teenager. She goes to school, she hangs out with her friends, she goes on dates. One day she goes on a date with this guy she's been dating a few times but doesn't really know all that well. This night they decide they are finally going to have sex. After a series of events which I won't spoil here, Jay is told by her date that this "thing" (from now on I'll refer to it as an entity) has been following him for quite some time and he has now passed the curse on to her (via sex) and the entity is going to start following her and that if it gets to her it will kill her. It can look like someone you know or it can be a stranger you have never seen before. It does what it has to do to get to you. The only way to get rid of it is to "pass it on" to someone else. Eg, have sex. He continues that there are ways to buy yourself time. It only walks so you can drive far away and buy yourself a few days before you have to keep moving again. The entity also only goes after one victim at a time and only those that are affected can see it (which begs the question who is real and who is the entity?). He concludes that it is slow, but it isn't dumb and that no matter where you are it will always know and it will always follow.ActingI think it's rare in horror films these days (for me anyway) to really care about the characters. They are either doing something stupid or out of character in general or they just aren't that interesting. Therefore I don't really care what happens to them. Sometimes the actors just suck at acting or they are given poor direction. For the most part I thought the acting in It Follows was really good. Maybe not the best, but better than most in the genre today. Maika Monroe in particular gave a wonderful and most importantly believable performance that was easy to accept. While the film does a good job on it's own of helping you buy into this world, Maika's acting really helps sell it. When she is supposed to be frightened you genuinely feel frightened. When she asks her friends if she is crazy you know she isn't, but at the same time based on the way she is acting you might think she was crazy. She plays a terrified character really well, but she also does a good job of showing bravery at times in regards to what she's going through. She's no Jamie Lee Curtis in Halloween, but I honestly think if Maika Monroe decides to persue the genre we could have another future "scream queen" on our hands later down the road. Along with the character of Jay we have her sister Kelly (Lili Sepe) and their friends Paul (Keir Gilchrest) and Yara (Olivia Lucardi). While I didn't think these actors and actresses did quite as well as Maika, I do think they did a good and servicable job. It's saying something that I didn't really hate any of them. They just didn't seem to feel all that important. I will say I really did like the sisterly bond between Kelly and Jay. It was believable. Kelly loves her sister and worries for her, but at the same time she is kind of jealous. It feels real and genuine. Paul is a childhood friend of Jay and Kelly who has had a crush on Jay for awhile now. He comes off as a bit meek and a bit of a push over at times, but he does show a sense of bravery later on and he is just trying to protect his friends. Yara is obsessed with this palm reader thing and just spouts off various sayings that happen to tie into what is happening around them. She isn't a bad character, there just isn't much character there. I don't fault the actress for that though. On the contrary I do think she did a good job with what she was given. There are one or two other pivotal characters, but I don't want to spoil anything. Overall I think the acting was really good. And when it wasn't I really couldn't fault the actors themselves. If anything I give them credit for being likeable characters who you do care about. That goes a long way in any film. CinematographyThis film looks great. From the very first opening shot which pans a full 360 degrees, within the first minute of the film, I was hooked. This 360 degree style of filming comes up a few more times in the film and it is used to great effect. This film also relishes in wide, open shots which slowly pull in center frame. There is a scene in this film, and one of my favorites, where it is just a car in an abandoned lot with a desolate buidling off to the right and the camera ever so slowly zooms in center frame. I absolutely loved it. It is a fairly simple scene and not much happens in it, but the way it is shot with the wide angles just feels ominous. The director really has a way of heightening the suspense just from how much scope of the shot you get to see. I find that for the most part as an audience our center of attention on the screen is, well, the center. It is because of this that we might miss some other elements in the background. The film also uses focus and lack thereof to mess with the audience. Sometimes the camera will focus on what's in front of you while the background is out of focus and you miss what is happening in the background until it is too late. Because there are these wide shots and out of focus shots it heightens the tension and paranoia. It is that sense of paranoia that really compliments the camera work and vice versa.SoundIn my personal opinion the use of sound and music can make or break a film. Most notably a horror film. Try to picture some of the most well known or best horror films without those iconic sounds or musical scores. "Halloween" without John Carpenter's theme? I think not. It might still be a little terrifying, but for the most part it would lose a huge amount of that sense of terror. It Follows knows how to use sound and when not to. This film does have one or two loud jump scares but they are there for a reason and they are effective at what they set out to do. The sound doesn't just scare you for a second and then ends, it lingers with you and drives that sense of dread. This is where the score/soundtrack shines. Ever since "Drive" came out in 2011, there seems to have been a sort of resurgence of modern day artists/composers adapting a more 80s electronica sound. It Follows's score from Disasterpeace is that same type of 80s electronica, but it does so better than any of it's peers. Most notably however is that this soundtrack takes most of it's influence from John Carpenter's own type of sound. This soundtrack would honestly fit right in with a horror film from the 70s/80s. I find that sometimes filmmakers use soundtracks as backgroud noise. Particularly in horror films. It feels as if it is just there because the film needs music. Occasionally it might spook you a little bit, but beyond that not much else. Going back to the whole problem with horror today thing, the use of sound can also be a film's downfall. In some films these days we are conditioned by the music and it deflates that tension that we had. What I mean by that is say you have a scene where one man is on-screen and then from off-screen a hand places itself on that man's shoulder and then the full character steps into view. In today's typical horror films some kind of musical cue would play at that last moment and tell the audience that this is the killer so they now know what to expect and that tension is gone too early. Or worse than that, the same secenario plays out and it's a false jump scare but the audience thinks he's the killer anyway because they associate that musical cue with the killer. There is a simple scene in this film that wasn't even a jump scare, but made me tense just because of what happened before and it turned out to be nothing. The fact that I still felt tense without hearing anything but footsteps and breathing is testament to the point I'm trying to make. In most of today's horror films, even if it was a false scare there would still be some obnoxious loud cue that would make you jump nonetheless. It Follows doesn't use these tricks. The score and audio compliments and accentuates the suspense and paranoia at all times.ScaresI feel like horror films have to be graded just a little different than films from other genres. You could see an action or drama film, but for the most part you know what you are getting yourself into and you know what to expect. With horror however, you expect to be scared or to feel something. I think it is because of this expectation that horror should be graded a bit different and maybe a bit harsher. At the opposite end of that spectrum I think if a horror film truly accomplishes it's goal (scares) in an effective manner then maybe it could be graded a little more lenient or rather certain minor faults could be slightly overlooked more than films from other genres. As I alluded to earlier, today's horror films have an obsession with jump scares and using them in all the wrong ways. It Follows still has one or two false jump scares, but it also uses jump scares that actually matter and are equally as effective. However, the real reason this film is being regarded as one of the best horror films in years is because of it's use of suspense, tension, atmosphere and the sense of paranoia that goes along with it. This is the stuff true horror is made of. The imagery in this film is disturbing at times to the point where I just tensed up in my seat and felt my pulse increase and mixed with the haunting score it was all the more terrifying. The film takes relatively normal looking people at times but just makes them absolutely disturbing. There is a scene in this film where it is just an old woman walking, but coupled with everything else it is truly terrifying. The paranoia created in this film is unnerving. Too many times during this film I felt like it was playing a demented game of "Where's Waldo?". I touched on it earlier, but the wide shots really add to that tension and paranoia. A few times I would see the rustle of a bush and look in that direction of the screen to find nothing. In an earlier scene I was looking to the far right of the screen because I thought I saw or expected to see something when in fact I missed what was center screen. I feel like with a broader scope for the audience to see it adds to that tension and paranoia because you are not sure where exactly to look. You expect something to happen but you're given so much to look at that you might miss something and then what happens next may surprise you. The cinematograpy mixed with the music and sense of dread really plays with the audiences expectations in the best way possible. I have said it before and I will say it again: I really do think that psychological horror is the most effective. It gets in your head and when it is really effective, it can mess with you by not even doing anything. As I mentioned in the beginning only the affected (or infected if you prefer) can see the entity. This adds another layer of tension because despite it exhibiting some fairly obvious mannerisms (the audience might realize, but the characters won't), from far away you can't be sure whether that person coming up behind Jay is real or not. That is the type of horror that makes It Follows so great.Negatives/ConsAt the risk of being biased I will say the film wasn't perfect (no film is.) While it has an inventive and clever climax, I do feel the final "confrontation" was a little bit of a let down. It was an interesting way of doing things and still enjoyable, but I guess for a final act I was expecting something different and a little more. Also every now and then I felt like some characters were underutilized or not as fleshed out as they could have been. Other than that I really can't find too many faults with this one.Miscellaneous ThoughtsI feel I have to mention how "timeless" this movie felt. I don't mean that in a "lasting" type of way so much as I mean literally. There were things that happened in this film that made it feel almost dream-like. Too many times during this movie I kept asking myself what decade is this set in. The television is a small box and plays old sci-fi films in black and white, but the police cars are more modern. The refrigerator is older and bulkier, but the girl has a slightly futuristic touch screen phone/palm reader thing. The theater they go to looks older and more retro, but the city and suburbs feel more modern. It felt really disorienting at the time, but not to the point that it was a distraction or a hindrance. It was actually a really neat touch that gave the film a unique feel. The director has gone on to say that it was intentional and supposed to make it all feel dream-like. Also, I wasn't sure how to fit it into a category, but the pacing of the film is perfect. It is not slow, but it's not break-neck fast either. When there are moments of down time it is still interesting and you are never really bored. The tension slowly builds, but once it does it never lets go. You are always engaged with what is going on with these characters. Finally, it is worth mentioning that I love how the film takes a timeless horror trope (you have sex, you die) and makes it lead to literal death. It's another example of taking something proven to work and making it fit in a way that feels fresh again. Overall, I loved this film. On paper It Follows shouldn't work at all. The concept alone sounds incredibly stupid. What it does so well is that it borrows elements from other well established entries in the genre and tweaks them just a bit to create something different and original. The story is unique and the premise is rather clever. The acting is great with likeable characters while Maika Monroe delivers a great and believable performance. The cinematography is excellent and really adds to the dread that is being portrayed and the story that is being told. It helps add to the tension that is present throughout the film. The sound in the film is amazing. The score is haunting and loud and piercing but it is that way for a very good reason. It Follows knows how to use jump scares and when to use them effectively. The scares in this film are perfect. They are sometimes subtle and cerebral, but always effective. The tension is unrelenting and the paranoia is almost constant. All of these elements combine to create something wonderful and unique. This film is an homage and love letter to classic horror from the mid 70s and 80s. It takes the best of those films and leaves behind the cliches that other films today rely so heavily on to make you "scared." The film has a few faults, and if you really want to nit pick you might find more, but nothing that really detracts from anything. I don't know if it is true, but I feel like sometimes with horror people go into it trying to be "macho" and trying to prove they aren't scared. I think this is sometimes why the genre gets a bad rep at times and I think it defeats the purpose of seeing a film of the genre in the first place. Movies are supposed to be fun and horror is no different. If you go in trying to sabotage that experience then yeah, you might be disappointed. You are supposed to go in and just accept whatever is about to happen with a normal mentality. If you go into this one knowing little and expecting to feel fear and unnerved, if you accept it, you won't be disappointed. It Follows is one of the best horror films in recent memory. It is a breath of fresh air in a genre that for the most part has been kicked around, mocked and left for dead and it is hopefully a sign of things to come. 8 out of 10

Great horror film. There is so much going on in this film that I don't know where to start. But let's start with the hook. It follows has a novel hook, the most intriguing hook since The Ring. The idea is that there is some kind of demon (for lack of a better word) whose attention is passed on from person to person through sex. A person so infected moves to the front of the queue until he or she finds a partner to pass the curse on to. And apparently if the demon touches the person at the front of the queue, he or she dies, and the demon moves on to the next person.And the demon operates according to some simple rules: it stalks its target by walking towards it slowly, which means that running away is easy. But the follower never stops. And its invisible to everybody but the target(s). The lead is Maika Monroe, who is nearly a ringer for Kids-era Chloe Sevigny. She's a relative unknown, as are the actors who play her circle of friends. This reviewer approves of the use of unknowns in horror films - it's a choice that makes viewers see the characters, not the actors, and makes all of them seem vulnerable. The writing for the young adult characters is superb - they have the right level of emotional maturity, with a mix of loyalty and insecurity that is just right. Monroe as Jay and Keir Gilchrist are particularly strong. I don't fathom some of the criticisms of the plot. Apparently some viewers disliked the slow pacing, which I thought was a good choice because this movie is much more than a monster flick (hint, hint). There are also criticisms of character logic, which I find particularly odd. Each character is working with his or her personal logic, and each makes sense in the choices made. Also: people don't immediately recognize that they are characters in a horror film (unless we're talking about 'Scream'). This film has a lot to say about human sexuality, and people who ignore that, and are looking for just a slasher film are going to be disappointed. But not only does It Follows work as a psychological study, it also works as an extremely scary horror film. It's the best horror film I've seen in years.

By now, everyone should know the drill: if characters in a horror movie have sex, those characters are as good as dead. They might as well paint a bull's-eye on their head, as the killer will instinctively flock to them with murderous intent. While being chaste does not necessarily guarantee one's survival, the odds are far better than for those who give in to sinful temptation. This is not a new concept; it's a trope as old as the genre itself, brought to mainstream attention (along with many other tropes of the genre) with John Carpenter's "Halloween." But filmmaker David Robert Mitchell has found something new to do with it, putting a whole new spin on the idea that sex will get you killed. The result is "It Follows," an insidiously suspenseful piece of work that, as the title would suggest, sticks with you. It's creepy and unsettling, and Mitchell displays a profound, Hitchcockian knack in building tension. When 19-year-old Jay (Maika Monroe) finally gives into the sexual advances of her new boyfriend Hugh (Jake Weary), she unwittingly puts herself in grave danger. Hugh breaks it down for her; apparently he is the victim of a terrible curse which was passed on to him after a one-night stand with a girl he met at a bar. This curse manifests itself in the form of a slow-moving, shape-shifting entity that follows Hugh wherever he goes, visible only to him. By sleeping with Jay, he has passed the curse on to her, and now she is the new target of said evil entity. The thing moves slowly, but if it ever catches up with its prey, it kills him/her. Therefore, if you're its target, you better keep moving. According to Hugh, there is no way to stop it; the only thing Jay can do is "pass it on" (i.e., sleep with someone else, thereby making that person the new object of the demonic entity's hunt). What's particularly clever about this set-up is that sex is both the catalyst for a person's demise as well as the only way to stay alive. But even then, there're no guarantees, for if the thing kills its current target, it will revert back to its previous one. So if Jay were to get caught and killed, it would go back to stalking Hugh, and if it got him, it would go after the girl who passed it on to him, and so on. There are all kinds of social allegories present here (you could basically look at the thing as some kind of lethal, sentient STD), but at its core, "It Follows" is quite an effective little horror film. The thing about "it" is that it always takes on the appearance of people, but the appearance is always changing. So if you're the target and you're in a crowded area, for example, it could be difficult to tell which member of the crowd (if any!) is your pursuer. The only real giveaway is the fact that it's visible only to you; so if you see an odd-looking person walking slowly towards you that nobody else can see, it's time to run. It's remarkable how effectively creepy this all is, considering its simplicity. The entity moves at a snail's pace, but like the Terminator or Michael Myers, it never stops. As Hugh explains, wherever the thing is, regardless of the distance between it and Jay, it will always be walking in a straight line in Jay's direction. She could hop into a car and drive across the country, but all that really does is buy time. Eventually, inevitably, it will catch up. This leads to some spine-tingling sequences in which Jay is forced to stop moving, and she-and the audience-nervously scan her surroundings, just waiting for the creature to turn a corner or pop into view. As with all the great horror films, the anticipation is nerve-wracking. I do have some issues with the film. I'm still not quite certain I understand what Jay and the other characters were attempting to do during the climax of the film, nor do I understand its resolution. And at one point in the movie, it appears as if Jay is about to "pass it on," but there is never any mention of this in the next scene, and it's unclear as to what ended up happening. Problems aside, "It Follows" succeeds in invoking feelings of unease and dread in the audience. It takes a well-established horror movie clich� and somehow forms a pretty original concept from it. In this instance, abstinence doesn't just make it harder for the monster to kill you; it keeps you off its radar entirely. In this universe, it just might actually be a good thing if you're not successful in landing that hottie sitting on the barstool next to you. The skeletons in their closet may be shockingly literal.

Let's be honest, in the 2010s the horror genre is again facing a crisis -reminiscent of the one that almost cause its extinction in the 90s- as every year a handful of forgettable and clich� filled films arrive. But in this phase of forgettable and laughable horror films there are a handful of exceptions ("The Conjuring", "The Bababook", and the more comedy than horror "The Cabin in the Woods"), so the question is: Can "It Follows" be a new member in that extremely short list of exceptions or is it another mess of a horror film? Jay is a teenager that just experienced her first sexual encounter, but this makes her the vessel of curse: An unknown being will follow her and will kill her in case of getting to her. In this dark phase for horror films, when one manages to get critical acclaim and achieve good word of mouth, fans of the genre are curious and excited to see it, so does "It Follows" live up to the hype? "It Follows" counts with a premise that sounds ridiculous but the execution is masterful, it pays homage to numerous films of the genre (specially certain John Carpenter�s films), an electronic score that works incredibly well with the story and it is used when is necessary, the cinematography is surprisingly straight out of an art house film and is the biggest star of the film, it masterfully creates an unnerving and highly suspenseful atmosphere, it takes advantage of some horror clich�s, a theme that's heavy handed but still works, and a slow pacing that's all about buildup. But even if this film has some greatness, it also has humongous flaws. There are some inconsistencies in the script, the setting is distracting as at times it feels like the 70s but then they use cell phones or have this ridiculous and bizarre sea shell Iphone (I get that it's supposed to feel like a nightmare but it is distracting and unnecessary), some story elements go nowhere, the acting is dreadful, the script needed a little background regarding the characters, most of the dialog is laughable, the characters are caricatures, the second half completely ruin the buildup of the first half as it lacks a payoff, the climax is laughably absurd and dumb, it has no resolution, and the pacing never gets faster even if the story demanded it. "It Follows", is an interesting take of this dying genre as it combines art house indie style with various 80s horror movie clich�s, and the result is this unsettling film with a heavy handed theme. It starts with a promising and highly suspenseful first half but it then deteriorates into an unintentional comedy. Worth seeing if you are a lover of the genre or if you like indie films.

While I admit that the dialogue in the film is lacking, this is one of the better horror films I've seen in a very long time.I've been trying for ages to find that special horror movie, the one that got under my skin and made me think about it at night when all the lights were out. The one that kept me awake at night. The one that I tried to forget when I closed my eyes. While It Follows didn't get that deep under my skin, and while it didn't keep me awake at night, it did haunt me, it stayed with me... and I couldn't forget it.After movies like The Conjuring and all of those other "demons, demons, demons" flicks, all that supernatural nonsense, psychic powers and Bibles and fire and possessions... I've seen it all, and I'm so tired of it... this was a very fresh return to what horrifies me most: psychological horror. The creeping sensation that something is after you, something that no one else can see. Demons, ghosts, witches, etc... none of that ever frightened me, because none of it is believable. But I can believe that someone can go insane and start seeing things, because that happens in reality. Demons don't possess people... but seeing an old woman walking toward you across the yard is possible. She may not really be there... and that's what's so terrifying to think. Are you crazy... or are you not?The question of whether or not we're "cracking up" or going insane truly is a very frightening one. The sense that someone is following us has been part of us for a very long time, and it always frightens us to feel that chill, that concept that there is someone right behind us, wanting to hurt us. I can only imagine the terror someone goes through when they first discover they're seeing things that aren't there... until It Follows came around. Then I saw a pretty good example of what that might be like.It Follows succeeds in capturing a very real feeling that some people go through, that someone is always out to get them, and there is nothing they can do but run. It gives you the sense that there are things other than bumps in the night to be afraid of. The fact that the monster walks, not runs, but walks toward you, is a pretty effective way of showing that it has nothing but time to catch up to you and eventually nab you. That's pretty chilling when you think it over.Some people are sniveling that the movie is too ambiguous, but I like it that way. I want it to be cryptic. I DO NOT need a movie to explain every little thing to me. Just give me something to work with, make it seem real, and I'll run with it if you can achieve that. I don't have to know "where the monster came from," I don't have to know "if it can be killed." I just want the director to make me believe in it. And that was a very successful attempt at doing so. He made me believe in the monster. Not many horror films do that to me anymore. None of them do, actually.I also have to comment on the soundtrack. My god, is it good. They're these gorgeously crafted synth tracks that really reach you and fill you with a sense of unease and even tranquility at other times. One of the best horror soundtracks I've ever heard since the soundtrack to Maniac.No, some things in the movie don't make 100% perfect sense, but it's not supposed to. You're supposed to be left wondering. If you don't like that, that's your deal. Movies have spent so much time explaining themselves to us that we feel like we're supposed to be told every little thing whenever we see a story. Movies have been holding our hands for generations, so when we don't "get" something, we get angry, rather than scratch our heads and discuss what we thought with others. Some things are just supposed to be concluded in your way. They're left up to interpretation by you. I like that everyone comes to their own conclusion at the end of the movie. Some say the monster can be destroyed. Others say it can't. I say it can't. Others would disagree. I like that. Not every ending needs to be over-analyzed, like the end to stupid Inception. If you come away from the movie getting angry asking yourself a bunch of needless questions, you might be overthinking it. And coming from me, that's saying a lot, because I overthink every movie I see. This movie was made in such a way where it was scarier NOT answering those questions. Some aren't, but some are, and this was.All-in-all, other than the Babadook, this was the best horror film I've seen in ages. Any movie that can haunt me does its job. Please, no more ghosts. No more demons. No more vampires or zombies or any of that crap. Just scare me, damn it. Make me uneasy. Make me feel trapped in a maze of my own mind. If a character hears voices in a film, I want to feel like I too can hear those voices. I want to be scared.It Follows seems to be guiding the horror genre in the right direction. Films, especially horror ones, have trained us that there is always some magical solution or deus ex machina to save the friggin day when real life doesn't work that way. I want movies to be true to life, because then I can relate to the characters, I can feel them, I can sympathize with them, I can react with them. If you want big-budget Michael Bay BS special booming effects and characters so fake that you can't take them seriously, there's plenty of brainless popcorn-stuffing superhero films to gorge yourself on.

I must sound like a broken record (or corrupted mp3 file) when I say that quality horror films are few and far between. A good horror film can keep you on the edge of your seat, thrilling you with clever scares or unnerving imagery. But any horror fan knows that in searching for a good horror film, you're going to see a lot of bad ones. Unfortunately, It Follows falls into the latter category. This film has a familiar beginning, though skillfully done: a teenage girl in red high heels bursts out of her house and runs out into the street then to her car. She runs, but doesn't get away. There is definite skill in the staging, and it was clear from the outset that this was aiming to be a low-key, subtle horror film, but something was amiss with that opening scene. The random teen girl being menaced in the first scene is not just a horror movie clich�, she, and those red high heels even more so, are a signifier that It Follows is a film that will emphasize style over substance. That would be forgivable if It Follows was engaging and scary. However, It Follows also emphasizes style over scares. The premise of this movie is intriguing and fresh. After having sex for the first time with her older boyfriend, young Jay (Maika Monroe) is attacked by him, drugged, and tied to a chair. He explains to her that he has passed to her a ghost that will follow her until it catches up with her and kills her. If it does, the presence will go back to following him. "It" can appear as anyone, even people she loves, and though it moves slowly it won't ever stop following her. There is nothing she can do to get rid of it, only pass it along to someone else. Though clearly aware of the allegorical implications -- STDs/AIDS, or adulthood/maturity, both of which amount to decay and death to a teenager -- the film never fully embraces this subtext, insisting that the theme is open to a broad interpretation.It Follows steers clear of some horror movie clich�s (there is almost no violence or blood), but falls into others (Jay's "nerdy" friend is characterized by big glasses and reading Dostoevsky's The Idiot). There are, of course, a few pop-up/startle scares. The climax is capped off with a creepy and memorable visual element. However, too many times I noted that while what I was seeing looked creepy, I wasn't actually creeped out or scared. Is that figure in the distance behind Jay "It" or just a normal person? Speed walking or a light jog in the opposite direction is all it would take to diffuse the situation. At certain points It Follows moves too slowly, and the non-scary scenes fail to build dread and danger. The "scare" scenes, or potentially scary scenes, are separated by scenes of Jay and her friends talking like they are adults on True Detective. They wax poetic about the line between the suburbs and the bad parts of town, but those ideas are not explored any further. The one consistently effective element of It Follows is the haunting synth score by Disasterpeace.I very much enjoy slow-burn horror films (Audition, John Carpenter's Halloween, and Val Lewton/Jacques Tourneur movies are some of my favorites). Because these films typically have low budgets, they avoid effects-heavy set pieces in favor of a grand, thrilling finale. The most successful examples make up for a lack of spectacle by building atmosphere and tension and creating full characters. It Follows clearly aims to be like the classic slow-burn horror films from the late 70s and early 80s, but ultimately it falls short in those crucial areas of mood and character and instead fills the time with dull teenagers talking to each other in rooms. Horror films can be flawed and still be successful. A good horror movie can have flimsy characters, plot holes, contrivances, it doesn't even have to make sense (I'm looking at you Suspiria and Hausu), but it must spook, unsettle, creep, disturb, or unnerve. It absolutely must scare and, even more importantly, entertain. It Follows did not have me anywhere near the edge of my seat. Instead I was slumped back, my mind wandering to memories of other horror movies.

The first time I watched "Halloween" was all the way back in October 2012, on Halloween night, to be exact. I was fifteen-years-old, had never considered myself to be a horror fan, and didn't have a clue what made the film such a hit among slasher buffs. Midway through the harrowing climax, my sister, who had gone out trick-or-treating all night, crept up to the living room's back window and banged on the pane as hard as she could. That should have been the fright of my life, but "Halloween", as it turns out, is so scary that a quick jolt hardly compares to the lasting disturbia of its nuts and bolts. Everything about it is straight out of a hyper-realistic nightmare you might have had after a night of anxiety attacks - the score, the acting, and of course, the sight of Michael Myers' mask are still enough to cause me to collapse into a puddle of yesterday's confidence. And despite the fact that the film is really and truly an exercise in horror, the scene that has lasted with me the longest is the final scene, which, after a few seconds of regrouping, cuts to a shot of Laurie Strode's lawn from the view of the balcony. There, the body of Michael Myers (recently shot) should have been strewn. But after barely recovering from her attack, Laurie peers over the ledge and finds him gone. On the loose. Ready to kill. Again. When putting my movie watching history into consideration, ambiguity is the tool that seems to make a horror movie work for me. My personal favorite, "The Blair Witch Project", was such a masterpiece because the fear was never fully explained, despite seeing monstrosity after monstrosity occur before our very eyes; and in other excellent works, such as "The Innocents" or "The Babadook", the villain on the prowl is kept invisible, while we collapse in fear over the mental detonation that befalls its protagonist.  Horror is one of the few genres that rarely seems to work - because the main goal is to scare, much of the plot points have a similar air, even the gems ringing with a sort of depressing familiarity. And considering the genre has been around since the 1920s, it seems to be, especially as of late, increasingly difficult to make a chiller completely new and completely disturbing. Finally, we have a mood piece worthy of the hype: "It Follows" is one of the best, if not the best, horror movie of the 2010s. It takes the best of Carpenter, the most subdued of Argento, and the ghostliest of Romero and makes for the most outrightly ominous terror train of recent years. It sticks with you - no, scratch that: it follows you - for much too long, individual scenes as impactful as the aforementioned finale sequence of "Halloween". As of right now, it may be denoted as a terrifying indie sensation that pushed past its low-budget constraints and broke the ground. But in twenty years, it might be a golden egg horror buffs gaze upon like a stack of one-hundred dollar bills, the knight in shining armor that saved the genre from completely collapsing into hardly seen independent fare. The monster stalking the premises is not an axe wielding murderer or a snaggletoothed demon but a soulless entity who menaces a victim at a time. The victim in "It Follows" is Jay Height (the wonderful Maika Monroe), a blonde college student whose life is turned upside down after spontaneously having sex with date. The guy (Jake Weary), it seems, did not undergo the act as a deed of passion but as one of necessity. He is being staked by the previously mentioned ghoul, who follows him, like a zombie, wherever he goes. Like an STD, the fiend seems to travel from victim to victim through intercourse - but if the person on the receiving end of the devilish transfer is killed, it goes right back to its previous owner. It's a cycle of the most vicious quality, making life a living hell for anyone touched by the curse. Jay, a heroine in the same spirit as Laurie Strode and Dana Polk, isn't content passably sitting like a helpless victim, doing everything she can to survive and figure out to end the problem, her clueless friends in tow. In concept alone, "It Follows" is intriguing to the highest caliber, but execution is what makes a film what it is and David Cameron Mitchell is an auteur of enormous potential. Some scenes have the specificity of a severely darkened Wes Anderson flick, others drowned in uncomfortably colorful dread only found in the finest Bava. He's intensely concerned about texture and sound - the tone, unrelentingly gutted by dread, is threatening enough to cause the Blair Witch to back off; the score, emulating "Halloween" and the chamber stealth of an Ennio Morricone scored giallo, sends a rippling effect of panic through the body. If it were flatly shot, "It Follows" would be frightening, but not emotionally stimulating. And because Mitchell's dynamic is so saturated and so eerie, we don't solely jump in fright at the nearest cat-at-the-camera scare; we feel so blatantly terrorized that we become certain that maybe it's following us. Ghostly, stylish, and deliriously terrifying, "It Follows" is a classic in the making, a supernaturally subtle piece of uncompromising power. It renews what we've come to love about the horror genre, injecting much needed adrenaline in the long suffering brand. More, please.

It Follows is one of the most refreshing horror movies I've seen come out in recent years. We seem to be getting past the whole torture porn phase of horror as a people, and returning to a more creepy atmospheric style. This movie reminded me a lot of some of the best 80's horror movies, particularly Halloween. The blood is pretty restrained, the music is creepy and electronic, and it's largely a story of young people being pursued by an unbeatable force that's always around the corner. It was apparently based on a recurring nightmare, and it has that vibe to it. It's not really outright scary, but it's definitely tense and creepy. The characters don't have a ton of depth, but they feel genuine and likable enough that we care about whether or not they get through their bizarre circumstances. It's nothing particularly revolutionary, and it's a nice return to a lot of the stuff I like about horror.

Something that the horror genre seems to suffer nowadays is lack of originality. Since "Cabin in the Woods", it is difficult to recall an original horror film. Unoriginal does not always mean bad, of course. Movies like James Wan's "The Conjuring" or the "Insidious" trilogy aren't original horror films, but are really solid homages to the genre, and they are successful at what they set out to do. "It Follows", however, is the rare film that manages to be both: A refreshing new take on the horror genre, and a love letter to the same."It Follows" follows (no pun intended) the story of Jay (Maika Monroe), a blondie that spends his days hanging out with her sister Kelly (Lili Sepe) and her friends Yara (Olivia Luccardi) and Paul (Keir Gilchrist) and is also dating Hugh (Jake Weary), who seems to be a promising candidate for a relationship. After a few dates, the night finally comes when Jay and Hugh have sex. However, instead of the after-sex cuddles, Hugh sleeps Jay with chloroform and ties her to a wheel chair. When she wakes up, Hugh explains him that she now has "it", meaning that someone will follow her in a zombie-esque way. This someone could be anyone, and can take many forms, although only she can see that someone. She mustn't be touched by it, because if not she will die and the "it" will return to chase Hugh. The only way to get rid of "it" is to pass it to another person by having sex with such. Therefore, "it" is like the deadliest, creepiest and most relentless STD imaginable...sort of."It Follows" is a highly stylish movie. David Robert Mitchell and cinematographer Mike Gioulakis tell the story through long takes and wide shots that allow Mitchell to be extremely playful with his direction. Directing a horror film is not easy: A great deal of balancing has to be made, and more if one is ambitious enough to dare write in interesting characters. That's what "It Follows" does so well. The direction is unique, and the characters are not the recycled horror film clich�s. They are also played by capable actors. Maika Monroe, who we've seen kick ass in the similarly nostalgic "The Guest", is much more visceral in the leading role. Did I mention the movie was scary? Oh, yeah. The amount of tension found from the excellent opening sequence (Which sets up the tone for the film perfectly) till the very last shot of the film is delightfully unbearable. Plus, Mitchell also adds a deliciously pulpy and darkly comic background to the plot, making its impact much sweeter and refreshing.But "It Follows" is more than that. It is also a throwback to the old John Carpenter-esque horror films of ye olden days. It can be seen in the peculiar setting, a Seattle suburb that is at moments calm and friendly, and in others extremely dreary, and that also seems to have no clear sense of time. The cinema is playing "Charade!" and the kids' clothing seem fresh out of a 60s sitcom. But Yara also likes to read novels out of a smartphone the shape of a clam. Yes, this movie is quirky. It is true that this may not appeal to general audiences: After all, if box office numbers tell us something, is that original content is most of the time not lucrative. But those horrors fans who seem unamused by the movies the genre has produced nowadays, definitely give this indie gem a go. This movie is sheer horror perfection.

It Follows is a clear homage to the golden age of horror and its directors, most notably the voyeuristic, tension building photography of John Carpenter and the sexual and body horror of David Cronenberg. It is essentially very much a 2 sided coin, 1 side being a refreshing and well visualized piece of horror that steps above the mountains of garbage out there at the moment, and 1 side, typical and by the numbers characters and closure. This film follows a group of teenagers, your usual suspects, as Jay, a 19 year old female, has a terrifying sexual encounter with someone she thought she could trust. Soon we realize that by having this sexual encounter, Jay would be followed by an unknown pressence, unless she slept with someone else to pass it on, although this entity appears to be relentless and we essentially get a tension fulled game of cat and mouse. When It Follows is good, its really good, David Mitchell clearly knows what he is doing when it comes to building tension, in camera effects and subtle horror, however the writing and certain elements of pacing leave an extremely sour and bland taste in our mouths. The script is largely to blame here, yet again written by Mitchell, his characters are in no way likeable, unique or stand out in any way. Emphasis is slapped on this matter mainly through the dialogue, which at times is extremely cheap, horrid and overly trying. It's annoying because there are writers out there that can capture the innocence, fear and immaturity of teenage life, however Mitchell doesnt seem to be that person. His writing is 1 note, very forced and we end up with shallow, lifeless and dead beat characters who we really dont want to fall in love with. He also doesnt know exactly how to wrap this one up, although his final scene is a brilliant stop note, we hum and haw over the majority of the final act, with a handful of scenes that pack a tense punch but nothing more. However It Follows makes up for all of this with its visual style, its array of innovative shots and its haunting score. The film 90% of the time looks fantastic, it has a great life like feeling to it, colours are simple and effective and the overall feel is superb. The shots are excellent, mostly when the entity is in the back ground, stalking its prey, it completely reminds you of Halloween, with is uber wide shots, that allow the audience, in their own time, to witness the threat at hand. However my favourite shot has to be, after Jay's sexual encounter, where she finds herself strapped to a wheelchair, the DOP decides to attach the camera to the wheelchair itself, giving you the lead characters reaction for the entire scene and a dizzying background and she is spun around. All this is brought even tighter together with a fantastic score bit Disasterpiece, its dark, industrial and highly retro. I like the theme of this movie, its clearly aimed at the fear sex within teenagers and potential threats that can come of this very human and common act and the way Mitchel majoritively plays with that is fantastic. However being slightly older, it feels slightly alienating, I found myself asking questions such as, why dont the teenagers do this, or that in order to evade the threat. This feeling is made even more apparent by the films lack of adult pressence, its obvious Mitchell has decided, artistically to remove it almost all together and although this does give a feeling of hopelessness towards the kids, its almost non existance hinders any audience over 30 of any real appeal. This is a minor point as, maybe what he was trying to achieve here was a decent horror film for teenagers and if thats the case, he has hit the nail right on the head, it has enough to frighten, thought provoke and give you goosebumps, however a more mature and deeper thinking audience, will struggle to get the degree of severity this film tries so desperately to convey. It has plenty of merit and Mitchel is certainly a force to be reckoned with, however this outing boxes in its audience and once its started hurtling towards the finish line, there isnt an awful lot left for a huge demographic. If your a horror buff i reccomend giving it a watch but this predominantly acts as a great horror film for teens and an okay attempt for everyone else.

It Follows is a truly remarkable film. The film's premise could have easily been reduced to a subversive piece of cult horror, but what writer/director David Robert Mitchell manages to achieve is nothing short of extraordinary; a truly masterful piece of art that's thoughtful, stylish, horrifying. When the film is not rendering its audience completely terrified, its presenting a layered story, complex with deeply felt human interaction and self introspection. This film's seemingly laughable premise, a sexually transmitted demon that plagues those who contract it with inescapable persistence, actually serves quite well as a vehicle to discuss societal shame associated with sexual encounters. The premise seemingly seeks to subvert the horror genre by offering us a literal curse that associated with sexual activity. This theme has permeated the horror genre for years. The bimbo cheerleader and the testosterone-filled jock have often been discarded as fodder for sadistic bloodletting in horror films for decades. This is not the point of It Follows. It doesn't seek to subvert the genre, it seeks to rise above it; offering instead something that is totally authentic and cuttingly true. It offers fresh perspective on our society's penchant for demonizing sexuality.  The main character, Jay, is, in the beginning, intoxicated by the promise of young romance and love as she is courted by a seemingly handsome and kind young man named Hugh. Eventually the two have sex. The passionate encounter turns traumatic though as Jay is let on to the fact that the her courtship was only a necessary means to pass on the demonic sexually transmitted curse and afterwards she is promptly discarded. Her friends and family and neighbors know that she has had this encounter and they know that she was used and unceremoniously discarded or worse. What follows Jay for the rest of the film is a walking demon that permeates her life, making it unbearable, and obstructing every relationship she has and destroying everything she hopes to do. Some have said it is allegorical of contracting a sexually transmitted disease. I agree the film is allegorical, but this meaning is far too simplistic. What really plagues Jay is shame. Shame that lingers in the back of her mind, that seems to lurk behind every corner and that can come in the form of a complete stranger or as someone she loves. Hugh mentions that it does this "just so it can hurt you." This sort of shame is the natural outgrowth of a society that is all too eager to judge the actions of others and to label people, particularly females, as sluts or whores. One can carry around this shame for a lifetime. The film's themes evolve in the end to more general notions of human mortality and of accepting one's own fate. It might seem a little scatological but it fit's the narrative arc rather well. Director David Robert Mitchell also films this movie with the direction of a man who has digested a lot of horror films in his day. It is colored by everything from Romero, Carpenter and Craven to Polanski and Dargento. I could name two dozen horror films that play as inspiration for this film. It feels like a piece of throw back pulp horror. The soundtrack is synthesized straight out of the early 80s, the camerawork feels like it was shot by the demon offspring of Carpenter and Polanski, and the supreme leeway given to the unaccompanied minors in this film evokes visions of a certain time spent on Elm Street. This movie caters to everything we loved about those horror films but it does not pander to them, which is what will make this film an instant cult classic. The only complaint I have about the film is the slightly disappointing third act which, despite its faults, dose still manages to terrify. If Mitchell had dreamed up a final showdown as well conceived as the films final two shots, it might have been the undisputed best horror film of the past year, but unfortunately for it, it comes in a close second behind The Babadook. Even so second best in that contest is still pretty good.

This is a real damn good horror movie, all things considered. It's the type of film that I think non-horror fans would enjoy as much as horror fans due to its subtext and heavy use of symbolism. Here's the thing about the movie, it's very smart movie, but the symbolism itself isn't exactly subtle. A 5-year old can figure out that the It the film so ominously refers to is either a metaphor for a sexual transmitted disease, which is why it's, obviously, transmitted through sexual intercourse, or it's a metaphor for the inevitability of death. The film even throws in several excerpts from books that heavily hint at this. While I think, with the way the film plays out, that it's a combination of both, I think there's more of the latter than the former. There's a certain reality in the way how some people try to find ways to prolong or delay something that happens to us all in the end. No matter what we do, we cannot avoid our own demise, and that's, essentially, what Jay is doing throughout the film. She's just trying to buy as much time as she can to see if she can find a way to either delay it or stop it altogether. So it's a film that doesn't only work as a horror film, but also as an existential drama. But, like I mentioned, it's not like the symbolism itself is really subtle. The fact that it's so easy to figure it out, and how they beat you over the head with it, takes something away from it. It might not be a lot, but it does, slightly, take away from it. With that said, I do think that the horror itself was incredibly well-executed. The film does an excellent job at constantly reminding you of what is at stake and what It is capable of doing once It gets its hands on whomever it may want at a particular moment. Essentially, It can take the form of anyone that would allow to go after the person it wants, in this case Jay. It walks very slowly, but It always finds where Jay is at. Because of that, there are certain scenes where you 'nothing' is happening and, randomly, you'll see someone walking very slowly towards Jay and it's on again. That's one of the things I love about this movie, it's the fact that it doesn't ever let you forget what's going on at any time. It can appear at any time, so you, much like the main character herself, are always on your toes, looking out for any suspiciously slow-walking people. The threat of It is ever-present and, because of that, I think the tension builds and builds and people will definitely find parts of this to be terrifying. I just think that it's very effective at getting a lot of scares out of something so simple. There's very little gore, outside of a very graphic death, that happens off-screen to show what It can actually do. I think it's all tension and the fear that It can literally appear when you least expect it. The hallway scene in Jay's house is particularly effective at this. I think the film not explaining what It is and where It exactly came from adds to it, the lack of explanation does not feel cheap in the least. I read this somewhere, but the fact that the film, somewhat, exists in a dreamlike world explains this in that when you're having a nightmare, you're not trying to get to the bottom of what's so terrifying about it. You're just trying to escape it. Plus, and this is something that's been debated, is that if sequels to this film are made, which I hope isn't the case, that you can explore the origin of It or look at it from the perspective of another person being followed by It. I just think that a sequel, while a good idea, would take some of the novelty away from what made this film so good in the first place. Getting to the bottom of it would ruin the mystery this film attained by not getting to the origin of It. I'm not saying that a sequel wouldn't be a good film, but it's just not something I'd want to see. While I think that the film gets better as I'm reviewing it, to the point that I'm upgrading it from 3.5 to 4 stars, it's a film that starts to fizzle out after Jay has sex with Greg. It definitely gets back on track by its climax, but there are some rough spots here and there. I think there's also something very interesting about the film and that is the people that follow her as It. The last person that follows her looks an awful lot like her father, they show a family portrait after the fact. It may not have been, but I'm curious as to whether or not there was something deeper going on there. Maybe I missed something, but I'm curious as to whether there was anything behind the last person looking so much like Jay's father. The score to the film is also top-notch and the film is well-shot, there's more thought put behind the framing of the shots than your usual horror film. So, all in all, in spite of a few flaws, this is an excellent horror movie. It just works on a much deeper level than just a straight-up horror film, yet it also provides great horror. There's not many films that can claim this, it's usually either one or the other. It's just an exceptionally made and written film. I think it's a film that actually gets better the more you think about it, it's not something that you're just gonna watch and forget about it by the next day. Highly recommend film right here.

When was the last no-nonsense horror movie that included actual scares? It may very well have been a decade, at the least. The Cabin in the Woods was good, but more as a mockery of how formulaic modern horror movies have become. The jump scares, the soundtrack that is more memorable than the score, and the shakey cam. Sweet Jesus, am I sick of the shakey cam. It Follows breaks away from all of those tropes, and is more akin to the old-school horror movies of the late 1970s and early 1980s. Halloween was the movie that came to mind. This is not a slasher movie though. There is no story behind what follows. It's some sort of material ghost that you can only see if it follows you at some stage in your life. And if it's following you, it will kill you in a sadistic, inhumane way. In order for it not to follow you, you have to have sex with someone, then that person will be followed. That is, unless it kills that person and starts following you again. With this paranoid of an atmosphere, I may point to The Thing as being more similar. What really crawled under my skin is how open the world was, yet there was no way to escape that paranoia. No matter where a character was, it would always follow. That is brilliant enough as it is. On top of that, since only those caught in the sexual circle (and the audience) could see the "monster," we, the audience, are then able to show plenty of empathy for those being followed. When no one else sees it, here we are, screaming, "IT'S RIGHT BEHIND YOU. NOOO." Director David Mitchell never had to shout out, "Look, the monster is there!" He allows the audience to do that, and thus we can become part of the group of heroes. That aspect is probably why I thought of Halloween, along with the fact that our main characters are all teenagers/young adults. Parents want no business with this, and the characters know not to drag them into it. Oh, and the score sounds very inspired by John Carpenter, and Brian Eno too. No single theme stood out for me, but in the context of the movie, the synth waves sunk me in my seat.And about empathy. David Mitchell, also the screenwriter, ditched any cultural references in character development. The only sign of it being modern day is one character's eBook makeup clamp. I don't think I saw any cell phones, not that they would have been handy anyway. It may seem unimportant, but without the necessity of cell phones, It Follows felt rather ageless. None of the characters were jabbing at modern celebrities. They were watching B-movies from the 1950s, like all of the hipsters do. Everyone could act like human beings and not rave about sex until we accept each person as monster bait. That was awfully nice of David Mitchell to do. In fact, he only made one of the several sex scenes look pleasant. After the first one, and the mythos of the monster is explained, sex quickly became an act of desperate survival. So when Paul finally gets his wishes to be romantic with Jay, we're not rooting for them. We're frightened because either one of them could be next on the monster's kill list. And they know it! Yeah, if you're a horror fan, I'm sorry that you're spending your time in reading this long review. Why don't you just watch It Follows and join me in a song of praise for a possible new era of horror?

It's been an extremely long time since a horror movie was able to get under my skin. This one did...big time. I'd not only call this one of the best horror films of the year, but one of the best in the last 20 years. It Follows successfully avoids everything that's been killing the genre. There's no box-office friendly PG-13 rating, it's not a remake, there's no excessive gore or torture, and no stupid found footage gimmick. This is classic suspense in the vein of Halloween, Don't Look Now and Rear Window. This is a horror movie that takes a uniquely simple premise and gets every bit of mileage out of it. This movie doesn't use cheap jump scares, it focuses on common psychological fears and paranoia. The direction is amazing, the cinematography is gorgeous, the acting is superb, and the retro 80s synth score is extremely unnerving. Is this every horror fans dream come true? No. Because this movie is different, and not everyone likes movies that are different. Some people just want the same old, same old. Is this a perfect horror film? No. There are some gaps in logic, especially in the third act. But none of it ever bothered me because this movie creeped me out and stayed with me days after I'd seen it. And I honestly can't remember the last time a horror film had that effect on me. If you're looking for gore and random loud noises, this isn't for you. This is classic 70s/80s inspired horror and gets my highest recommendation.

If Mitchell wanted you to leave the movies feeling agitated, wanting more but also disappointed because of unanswered questions, then he did a great job.The movie however, becomes repetitive to the point where you almost need the above answered. BUT - the intention is not to really give you any reasoning, which adds to 'its' never ending journey. It's also the reason I kept double checking that my door was locked every night for a week before going to bed after seeing it. I still needed some closure, so I researched more on the movie.The thing that put me off was the Director, David Mitchell's comments on the film and where 'IT' came from, "I'm not personally that interested in where 'it' comes from."
